Abstract: This study revisits the Challenge–Hindrance Stressor Framework, proposing an evolved model that integrates contemporary insights from the Transactional Theory of Stress, Conservation of Resources theory, and the Job Demands–Resources model. By examining the role of appraisals and the influence of negativity bias, we aim to refine the understanding of how individuals perceive and respond to stressors in the workplace. Our analysis suggests that the traditional dichotomy of challenge and hindrance stressors may oversimplify the complex interplay of cognitive and emotional processes involved in stress appraisal. We propose a nuanced framework that accounts for individual differences in resource availability and personal goals, offering a more comprehensive perspective on stress management. This updated model has significant implications for organizational practices, suggesting tailored interventions that enhance employee resilience and well-being by aligning job demands with personal and organizational resources. Future research directions are discussed to further validate and expand this framework.
